This brings us to a fairly fundamental question about what sort of democracy we live in. I believe, as I suspect Melissa Manson does, that people should not be compelled to vote—as apparently do a significant portion of our population. A recent Herald Sun survey indicated that 63 per cent of those voting were opposed to the ridiculous notion of going to gaol as a sanction for not voting. Mind you, it was a non-compulsory survey!

The debate about compulsory voting often revolves around the issue of which party would tend to benefit the most. This is understandable, given the heavy reliance of the major parties upon the administrative arms of their organisations. It is indeed a brave decision to contemplate the move to completely new strategies of campaigning. Although this appears to be a comfortable decision to make, it lacks the moral weight, as I shall argue.

The ALP argue for the retention of compulsory voting because they feel that, under a voluntary system, they would lose proportionately more votes through non-voting than would the Liberal Party. In protecting their electoral interests, the ALP usually couch their arguments in the language of preventing certain disadvantaged groups from being disenfranchised—a result that they presume would occur under voluntary voting. Senator Faulkner's speeches in 1997 on the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill are a case in point.

The flaws of the approach by the ALP regarding compulsory voting are twofold. Firstly, it adopts the usual conceited approach, which is the `we know what is best for you' mentality. In this case, in spite of your own opinion on the matter, voting is deemed to be good for you and hence you should be forced to do it. Anyone who has even a passing respect for the principle to freely associate and, equally, the right not to associate should reject this mentality.

Secondly—and this severely undermines what little moral credibility existed in the first reason—there is the notion of protecting one's own electoral interests. Again, I refer to Senator Faulkner's speech as Leader of the Opposition in the Senate on 17 June 1997 as a typical example of the Labor line. Similarly, when Senator Carr outlined the groups that he also believed would be disenfranchised by the voluntary vote, he finished with the line:
. . . and it especially disadvantages a group in the community who are known to be supportive of the republic.

Labor's political motives now become apparent: replace the words `the republic' in Senator Carr's comment with the words `what I believe in' and I would suggest that this is a truer indication of the motives of the ALP in their support of compulsory voting.

Many Liberals agree `in principle' with the idea of voluntary voting but are concerned about the unknown effects it may have in elections. However, on this front the jury is still out. I refer to a recent paper of March 1999 in the journal Electoral Studies by Simon Jackman of the Department of Political Science at Stanford University. Jackman investigates the so-called `conventional wisdom' which holds that the conservative parties would gain under voluntary voting in Australia. He strongly qualifies this idea by noting that there have been only two comprehensive studies on this issue in Australia. These were in 1986 and 1996, by McAllister and Mackerras. Further, Jackman notes that Liberal Party MHR and former Victorian Liberal Party state director Mr Petro Georgiou rejected these findings. Jackman's study concluded:
In short, there is tremendous uncertainty about what is widely understood to be a profound change in the conduct of Australian electoral politics.

My point in all of this is that this issue should not be driven by predicted electoral outcomes by political parties but by principle. As I have stated earlier, the jury is still out in terms of electoral effects, but restricting the debate to voter outcomes is to adopt the approach of the ALP. The ALP's position is founded on electoral opportunism pure and simple. This ought to be rejected.

Voluntary voting is an issue of principle, and that principle is the democratic right to vote for the candidate who you believe will best represent you—and this should include the right not to choose a candidate. Back in the 1970s, the Liberals supported a compulsory arbitration system due to fear of the unknown risks of workplace bargaining. Thirty years later, the primacy of workplace agreements is supported widely, including by most of the ALP. Just as we have matured in the workplace, so should we mature at the ballot box.

Compulsory voting does not protect democratic freedoms. How could anyone argue that, in order to protect your democratic freedoms, you will imprisoned unless you exercise your democratic right to vote? As Lawrence Money humorously noted about Melissa Manson in the Age on April 30 this year:

. . . technically, if Ms Manson were jailed it would not be for refusing to be compelled to exercise her freedom of choice but for refusing to be compelled to turn up to refuse to exercise her freedom of choice.

Ms Manson decided that no candidate was worth voting for. What moral principle in our society allows the full force of the law, to the point of gaol, to compel her to pick up her ballot paper and return it blank to the ballot box?

Democracy is not protected by compelling people to be in a particular place at a particular time every three or so years. If advocates really believed all the rhetoric about why forcing people to vote is good for them, they ought to be advocating measures to ensure people fill out their ballots correctly. In the interests of protecting people's freedom, perhaps the Electoral Commission should be authorised to ensure that an individual not just collects their ballot but actually fills it out correctly! I would think not.

There are some who argue that if we have compulsory voting we should put a box on the ballot paper for `None of these'. Others go further and suggest people should be able to elect `No-one' if none of the candidates are any good. All of these suggestions and some even more ridiculous ones are put forward to get around the moral and philosophical objections to forced voting.

I am reminded of the system in the Soviet Union where conscripts in the military would be marched in to cast a vote for the one person whose name was on the ballot paper. The full oppressive force of the state, with the promise of the Gulag, was used to ensure compliance. We do not have a Gulag and we do not march people in, but we do gaol them if they do not turn up, accept a ballot paper and return it to the ballot box—even a blank ballot paper.

There are around 20 countries in the world where voting is compulsory. These include Bolivia, Cyprus, Egypt, Honduras, Singapore, Venezuela and Australia. They do not include countries such as Great Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Germany, the rest of the European Union, Japan or the United States of America. These are countries that have democracies as robust as anywhere else in the world. I argue that Australia has nothing to fear in contemplating a voluntary voting system. It is a debate that this country should embrace and should embrace soon in the interests of freedom.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Democrats Policy

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees says she is on a mission to make the GST fair.
—It is mission impossible.

—To make the GST fair, in the words of Tom Cruise, is mission impossible. You cannot make the GST fair. The newspapers this morning contain several articles about what a truly ramshackle tax system we will have if the GST is entrenched as a new tax system. Let me state very clearly yet again that the Labor Party is opposed to the GST. Labor supports tax reform; what we do not support is a regressive tax that is applied to everything we buy. Remember, even if food is exempted, there is still a tax on clothes. Exempt books, there are still magazines. Exempt bus fares, there are still taxi fares. Exempt bread rolls, there is still a tax on rolls with a cheese topping. Exempt bread, there is still a tax on a pie and sauce at the footy. The necessities of life are still under threat with any deal the Democrats may do with this government.

speech.para: I note that the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday reported that the Democrats believe that Labor Party stooges are being organised to ring in and to fax them to register opposition to any deal with the government. I have got some news for the Democrats: if people are ringing, faxing and emailing the Democrats, they are not from the Labor Party. They are probably the same thousands of people, small business people, pensioners, ordinary Australians, that faxed, phoned and wrote to Senator Harradine to register their short-lived relief when they thought the GST was dead and buried. I suspect they are real people communicating their concerns to the Democrats.

So for Senator Lees there are some hard policy decisions that have to be made in the next few weeks with not only those people but all Australians in mind. Labor wants to make sure that any decision of the Democrats that is made is made for the right reasons. After all, the Australian Democrats are the party that says it wants to `keep the bastards honest'. But they want it both ways.

On Monday, Senator Lees made it clear that rank and file party members will not have a say in the negotiations of the government on the GST. She was asked by a journalist: `If the deal is struck, will it have to be referred to Democrat members?' Senator Lees answered: `No it won't, because we're within policy.' I ask the question: is it within policy? Democrat taxation policy was balloted to members in June 1998. The results were reported in December 1998. There are two relevant areas concerning the GST package. First, under item 6, members agreed to `option C', which states:

The mix of taxation between direct (income) and indirect (expenditure) sources shall be restructured to increase the proportion of direct tax (increasing income tax and/or wealth taxes) relative to indirect tax.

That is, Democrat policy demands no tax mix switch from direct to indirect taxation. The government's GST package involves a $19 billion tax mix switch from direct to indirect taxation—a net $6 billion increase in indirect tax plus a $13 billion decrease in direct tax. Unless the Democrats are able to negotiate this away, they will be supporting a measure in direct breach of their own balloted policy.

Senator Lees is wrong. The government's GST package is so far outside the Democrat policy that if the Democrats' internal processes mean anything at all a new ballot should be held. The Democrat position, as far as we know it, is to cut back some of the tax mix switch as follows: the $6 billion increase in indirect tax would be reduced by the Irish food option, that is $4 billion. However, the Democrat option of denying $2.5 billion in diesel fuel credits will actually increase indirect tax by that amount, wiping out 60 per cent of the food measure. Any change to income taxes would have to be enormous to even get the Democrats to their policy starting point.

But the second breach of Democrat policy relates to the flat rate GST that they are moving towards. Items 7(B) and 8(B2) in the Democrat ballot specifically allow that `the indirect tax system shall be restructured to allow for tax to be levied on the provision of services as well as on the production of goods' but only if the GST is `set at several different rates'. The government's proposal is for a flat rate 10 per cent GST. Democrat members specifically rejected the proposal 8(B1) that `an indirect tax shall be set at a flat rate with almost no exceptions'.
Let me remind the Senate of the Democrats' tax policy at the last election. It was based, I presume, on the June members' ballot. It stated on page 3:
We have engaged in a full debate within our party on the best way forward, as well as trying to broaden out the national debate beyond the issue of a GST.

What did the policy say? What were the Democrats' promises? Most importantly, it sets out the Democrat `non-negotiables' and they include `taking the GST off food', `taking the GST off books', `restructuring the tax cuts to reduce the benefits to high income earners', `restructuring the new tax concessions on diesel and petrol'. These were all non-negotiable. These were all core promises and people who voted for the Democrats were entitled to believe that the party that pride themselves on keeping the bastards honest would themselves be honest—that non-negotiable means just that: it means non-negotiable.

The Democrats' tax policy went on to describe what was negotiable. They listed a series of issues that were `placed on the table for negotiation'—tourism packages sold offshore, payroll tax, federal funding of local government, family assistance. So we had two categories of policy—`non-negotiable' and `on the table'. What did we hear last Sunday? The leader of the Democrats on the Sunday program took every non-negotiable—that is, food, diesel, fuel, books, tax cuts—and put them on the table to be negotiated away. Despite their promise contained within their policy document, nothing is now non-negotiable. They are all now non-core, negotiable promises. The transcript of the Sunday program is very interesting. It reads:
OAKES: Now, you went to the election last October, saying a number of things were non-negotiable in your tax proposals. One of them was taking the GST off books.
LEES: Mm-hm.
OAKES: Non-negotiable then, still non-negotiable?
LEES: It's all still on the table and . . .
OAKES: That's different from being non-negotiable?
LEES: . . . absolutely everything that we took to the election is on the table . . .
OAKES: But, Senator, the Democrats exist, you say, to keep the bastards honest. You told the people these things are non-negotiable . . .
LEES: Absolutely.
OAKES: Now you're in discussion with the government, you won't say that they're non-negotiable. What are we to conclude?
LEES: Well, they are on the table . . .
OAKES: But are they non-negotiable?
LEES: (Sighs) All of the issues that we took to the election are on the table at the moment. Nothing, absolutely nothing, has been taken off by either side. Can I stress that? That when . . .
OAKES: Okay. You were the one who said they were non-negotiable, back in October.
OAKES: . . . If they're now being negotiated, that's something different.
LEES: The entire package is being negotiated.
OAKES: Okay. Now, you say that restructuring tax cuts to reduce the benefits to high income earners, that was non-negotiable.
LEES: That is on the table . . .

That is exactly right. Everything that was non-negotiable—everything—is now on the table. What we want to know is what is going on under the table. Let us have a look at what the Democrats have promised. Try Senator Lees in the Australian on 18 May 1999:
It's not an ambit claim. We're not about to start taking items out.
On food, the Sunday Telegraph on 11 October stated:

Democrats Deputy Leader Natasha Stott Despoja called for all food, including restaurants and fast- food outlets, to be exempt from the GST. ". . . I don't believe we can say to people on low incomes, it's okay to buy supermarket food but it will be more expensive for you to have a takeaway burger or confectionary."
On books, at the campaign launch for the Democrats Senator Lees stated:
Democrat senators and lead candidates have all pledged that we will not at any time—
not at any time—
support the new tax on food or on books.
On tourism, on 20 May 1999 Democrat spokesman John Schumann said:
We have spent a lot of time and resources going around the country promoting our platform on zero rating of travel packages. We are not now, nor will we, move away from this aspect of the GST.
What about the Australian Democrats' policy on `truth in political advertising'? Let me quote that:

Australians deserve much better political advertising standards. The Australian Democrats believe that legislation is necessary to prevent false or misleading political advertising. This would help to restore trust in politicians and the political system.

If trust is the bottom line, why have we seen this redefinition in relation to issues that previously were non-negotiable now being on the table? If trust is the bottom line for the Australian Democrats, why are all of the discussions with Senator Lees and other senators from the Australian Democrats now shrouded in such secrecy? Mr Howard is notorious for shrouding his activities in secrecy, in failing to communicate to the public, but I would acknowledge in this chamber that Senator Lees is normally up-front, much more up-front than Mr Howard.

The Senate still has not seen the additional material that the government has provided to Senator Lees in her `behind closed doors' discussions with government ministers. This is the material that she publicly chastised the government for withholding. Why is that material still unavailable to other senators in the chamber? Why is it unavailable to the Australian public? We have not had a decent explanation about this material and about what compromises are about to happen.

It does appear that there is a rule about transparency for the Democrats and apparently there is another rule for the rest of us. Senator Lees is being, in my view, opaque—I will admit and acknowledge uncharacteristically opaque—and a step in the right direction for Senator Lees and the Australian Democrats would be to practice what they used to preach and release this new material to the opposition, release it to the Australian public. As far as the opposition are concerned, we are happy to give the Democrats a hand in analysing this material.

But if they are Democrats they should act democratically. The Democrat leadership should be taking to their own party members any renovated tax package. They should take any deal back to the Democrat members. I say to the Democrat leader, Senator Lees, and her parliamentary team: act like Democrats. Practice what you preach. Do the right thing. If the deal that you are coming to behind closed doors with the government slides away outside the parameters that your own membership has set for you, have the courage to reballot them. If a hotch-potch deal is struck, if a GST is introduced, if the tax system goes truly ramshackle, if environmental standards slip, if the surplus is eaten away, then Australia will be the worse for it. So will the Democrats be the worse for it both as a political force and as a genuine political party with some sort of reputation for decency in Australian politics. The Democrats are lining up to be blamed for the Howard-Democrat GST. That is what Senator Lees is doing. She is lining up her own political party to be blamed, and the way it is going she and the Democrats will deserve all the blame they get. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Drugs: New South Wales Drug Summit

talk.start.para: —When I last rose to speak on matters of public interest it was the fifth speech I had given on the drug crisis at that stage and I said that it was going to be my final one. But since that time I have attended the drug summit in Sydney and feel that, as that was such a landmark discussion in the whole issue of handling the drug crisis, I should make some comments on the outcomes of that summit because what will now happen is that there will be certain moves in public policy resulting from the findings of that summit. The summit was opened by Premier Bob Carr. His opening statement was:

speech.para: Drug use is part of our society, part of our culture, part of the Australian way of life.
They were poignant words and it was a sound way to start this summit because the Premier was heralding an event which we have never undertaken in this country before.

What was significant about the event, apart from the fact that it went for five days, was that it had all the state MPs there but it also brought together in the chamber—and it was in the upper house chamber of New South Wales—a whole range of experts on this whole issue of drugs. We heard from people who were drug addicts. We heard from people who had children who were drug addicts. We heard from people who care for them. We heard from the police. We heard from community organisations who assist in this field. So what we had right at the start was a massive range of information, a range of facts, put before the summit. One of the problems, particularly when we get into this debate on whether our approach should be harm minimisation or whether it should be tough on drugs, is what the Sydney Morning Herald editorial characterised as `Drugs: a false dichotomy' and it talks about the false dichotomy between zero tolerance and harm minimisation.

This was one of the great strengths of the summit: people had their particular views, but they sat and listened. How much they took in and how much they changed their views varied. Towards the end of the summit, a number of people—including the Premier, Bob Carr—indicated that they had changed their views on several matters, based on that evidence. Premier Carr highlighted a key point in his opening address, saying:
I would not like the test of the effectiveness of this summit to be whether at the end of five days there is to be an endorsement of a heroin trial or safe injecting rooms.

Given what happened five days later, which I will come back to a little later in the speech, it is interesting that he made those comments at the start of the summit. Even though it was a great exercise in bringing out information, I think the outcomes were quite mixed and in many ways disappointing.

We have got to ask how effective the summit outcome was when one of its key recommendations was supervising legal, safe heroin injecting facilities, provided local governments agree after community consultation. It begs the question: if people are going to use safe injecting rooms, where are they getting the substance from to inject? Obviously, they are buying it off the street. A lot of them are affording to buy it through the proceeds of crime or prostitution. This terrible aspect of the problem—people turning themselves into criminals to support this habit, which impacts on society by increasing the rate of crime across the community—is not answered in any way by that recommendation. You have to ask yourself how effective it is as a strategy when many of the councils which have to bring in the ordinances to set up such an injecting room in a particular area express grave doubts. Many of them have already said that they just will not do it. How effective is it as a strategy when overseas experiences show that shooting galleries are not the real answer?

talk.start.para: —Shooting galleries are not the same.

—How effective is the long-term goal of reducing drug dependency? Senator, that should be the key goal: we should be trying to reduce drug dependency. What that strategy does is maintain people in a very poisonous and destructive habit and, of course, it does terrible damage to their lives and the lives of people around them.

speech.para: I want to comment on some of the views put forward by some people attending the summit. Police Commissioner Peter Ryan did raise some very important perspectives. He recognised that what was needed was a collaborative whole of government approach, but he said that police need very clear, unambiguous laws and a clear sense of the powers they have in particular situations. He was indicating particularly in this area of enforcement of drug law that that did not exist at the moment. He also pointed out—I think this is relevant in light of that last point of setting up shooting galleries—that in the area where you set up these sorts of facilities, as has been the case with the current syringe program and the methadone program, you create what he called a honey pot effect. This is what is causing the councils enormous concern. In other words, if you have got people who use drugs attending at a particular geographic point, that then actually attracts drug dealers. Remember that under the proposal the people in these rooms are not going to be given heroin. They buy it on the streets, so the street sellers are attracted to that area. That attracts crime to the area. That then degrades the whole area and people start moving away, and you have a degradation of your urban environment.

If people are going to have access to such facilities, where are they going to go? There was one set up at the Wayside Chapel. That is no longer running, but when it was set up, there it was for a city of four million people. Are they going to come in from Cabramatta or the North Shore or wherever to this one facility? Is it just going to be for heroin? In the case of some other illegal drugs, people sometimes take up to 16 hits a day. If they are doing that, they are going to do a lot of travel getting in and out of centres. Perhaps the only other answer is to set these up right across the whole city. Then you have the problems I indicated earlier with the honey pot effect, degrading the urban environment and creating centres of crime. What is happening in Cabramatta at the moment would be happening right across Sydney.

Nowhere in the world has this been shown to be a successful strategy. The mayors have really come out very much against it, as outlined in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald this week. I thought the most interesting comment was from the mayor of Fairfield, the council covering the Cabramatta area. He said that there was no room for approval of such a facility in Cabramatta by his council. The mayor of Lismore said that the Nimbin trouble spot would have strong opposition from the community. The mayor of Dubbo said there was a 100 to one shot that this would get up in his town. Even the mayor of Newcastle, who is in favour of drug trials, was quite cautious, saying that it would need very wide community consultation before they would dip their toe in the water.

The reality of this program is that it would have to be set up in some geographic location, and everyone living in that location would take what is called the NIMBY approach—`not in my backyard'. Even if it did get through council it would have great difficulty getting established. So it was a major recommendation of the summit, but as I have pointed out, it has major implementation problems. It will not solve the drug crisis. It is really heading in the wrong direction.

The right direction, which we should set our sights on very carefully, is rehabilitation. What families tell me is that they want their children off drugs. They don't want them maintained on drugs. This point was made very clearly by Major Brian Watters. One of the more saddening aspects of the summit was the way in which people who were still in their trenches, who opposed the approach of Brian Watters, attacked him in their questioning more so than anyone else that I saw. I thought the way they treated him was disgraceful. He pointed out that 98 per cent of Australians don't use heroin, so you cannot argue that programs that are in place are totally ineffective. That has been the background argument; a lot of people have said, `Well, nothing is working, let's try something new.' If 98 per cent of Australians are not on heroin, maybe something is working.

The strongly emphasised thing to come out of the summit is that the whole problem is basically under-resourced. The police do not have enough resources to enforce control of crime in this area. In particular, the rehabilitation facilities do not have enough resources, and this is the most disgraceful aspect of the problem. In my own state of New South Wales, which has half of Australia's drug problem, there are just so few detox facilities, for example. In the Hunter Valley, which has half a million people, there is one 16-bed unit. In the Central Coast, which has a quarter of a million people, there is no unit at all.

What came out of the summit was the need to have one of these units for about every 80,000 adults. That is equivalent to a federal seat, so that gives a rough calculation of how many units there should be. In my area—the Central Coast, the Hunter Valley—there should be seven units; there is one small unit. So the state government, which controls these things, has got a long way to go to put in better, more comprehensive treatment.

Major Watters indicated how this treatment works. He said that every dollar you spend on it returns $7 in benefits to the community. Getting people off drugs means less crime, less insurance, less time in courts and in prison. One dollar to $7 is a pretty good investment in improving our society. Major Watters also emphasised the point that I made in one of my speeches here about what is happening in Sweden. He put forward some very impressive statistics from Sweden. The lifetime prevalence of illicit drug use in those aged 16 to 29 years is nine per cent in Sweden; it is 52 per cent in Australia. The estimated users per million of population is 500 in Sweden and between 5,000 and 16,000 in Australia. What is Sweden doing that we are not doing to bring about these outcomes? What did a country that had a major drug problem in the seventies do in the eighties and nineties to get that under control?

Sweden brought in a combined package which increased the number of residential treatment centres, established outpatient units, updated public information campaigns, and deemed as unacceptable all non-medical use of drugs. So they combined a tough approach with a case management approach, putting resources in to treat people on drugs. That is the clear message from Sweden. It was a clear model that this country could have followed. Yet some of the things said at the summit and some of the recommendations made have us moving down a totally different path.

It was a very interesting few days listening to the speakers at the summit. It was a great pity that I was not a delegate. I would have liked to have been a delegate, but one of the shortcomings of the summit was that it was held in the upper house of the New South Wales parliament, with very limited seating. It would have been much better if the organisers had chosen, for example, the Sydney Convention Centre, where not only a lot more people could have participated but also a lot more people could have observed. Not at the summit were people from the Hunter Valley whose children had been on drugs; these people had held seminars and public meetings on drugs, yet they could not even get a seat to observe the summit. That was a great pity. With that wider participation, the summit would have had a much better effect.

I am very pleased that New South Wales undertook this summit. We will have to look at some of the recommendations in a very hard way. But by focusing the attention of all MPs on this problem for one week, I am quite confident that what will come out of it—particularly given the poor record of New South Wales—is much better resourcing of the drug crisis.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Public Opinion

talk.start.para: —The last time I spoke in this chamber on the GST was last Friday week. I have asked a few questions in question time this week, but last Friday week was the day on which Senator Harradine made what is now commonly called his `I cannot' speech. That was a quite historic speech in this chamber, a speech in which he declared that, in all conscience as an Australian, he could not vote for the GST in the form in which it currently appears; nor could he vote for the GST in the form of the offer made to him by the Prime Minister in negotiations the previous day, and indeed that day, to try to encourage his vote.

speech.para: It is important to follow the theme of public opinion that has been expressed by various polls and by various columns of letters to the editor to see what the Australian public think of the GST. A lot of people are claiming to speak on behalf of the Australian public. I think it is important that we look at the polls to see what they say to the pollsters and to get a fair feeling of the pulse of this nation when it comes to this regressive tax.

The Herald Sun newspaper, the weekend after Senator Harradine made his historic `I cannot' speech, took a poll to see whether Australians approved of his actions. The findings of that poll were that 70 per cent of Australians did approve. Going by that poll, they approved of them by virtue of Senator Harradine's declaration of conscience and the courage with which he had acted. Seventy per cent of Australians admired and respected his decision and held that it was right for him, a politician, to take a moral stand—and a courageous one—with respect to this tax.

But that 70 per cent means that a lot of people who are supporters of the GST also approved of Senator Harradine's actions, given the moral stand that he had taken. That is an important demonstration of respect for integrity, honour and honesty in political discourse in this nation, an important acknowledgment of the fact that Australians will approve, even if they disagree, when they recognise someone taking a moral stand, a stand on principle.

It is a matter of historical record that the Australian Labor Party has taken a stand against the GST, and has consistently done so. We looked at options for tax reform in 1985. In that context, we looked at a series of options. We took those options to a national summit of all interested organisations and, through a process of political debate, rejected the GST.

We also took a stand in the 1993 election, when John Hewson was the then leader of the coalition and introduced his notorious Fightback package, which was a GST package. On principle and in conscience, we took a stand on our electoral life against the introduction of a GST and fought an election on that issue. It is a matter of historical record that we won that election because Australians at that time rejected the idea of a GST.

The 1996 election, the one in which this government came to power, was an election in which you will recall this government had declared, through the Prime Minister, that it would `never ever'—and I quote those words—introduce a consumption tax into Australia. In 1996 that was not an electoral issue. But last year it was.

At the election in 1998, the government sought a mandate for a GST. It put forward such a proposition almost immediately before declaring an election and before Australians had been able to study the fine print of what this new tax meant. It is only because of the Senate's inquiry into that GST package that we have now discovered a number of major flaws. The devil in the detail has become apparent. The hidden traps and the burrs in the saddle are now public knowledge. We now know this to be an unfair tax; we know it to be a tax that you cannot make right.
I go back to the remarks made in this chamber last Friday week by Senator Harradine—which are, as I say, widely admired in Australia for their honesty and integrity—when he said:
One of the fundamental principles—
referring to the GST—

is the capacity to pay. I think people all around this chamber will agree that the GST is inherently regressive. We all agree with that. The question is whether compensation is adequate. That is the question in my mind that is raised for the government.
The question now in my mind is whether it is inherently regressive to such an extent that it should not be supported.

I want to draw particular attention to the next set of remarks because they go to the core of the debate as it has now moved. The debate now focuses on whether food should come out of the package; and, if food comes out, will the package therefore be fair?

The next remarks of Senator Harradine summarise a position that the Labor Party holds also—they are remarks which summarise the position to be taken by any fair-minded Australian who, after looking at the proposition of whether you can make an unfair regressive tax better, would say, `Of course you can't.' These are the remarks of Senator Harradine:

The GST burdens the poor and those with the least capacity to pay. It discriminates against the poor and the pensioners who are living a hand-to-mouth existence and spending the bulk of their income on the necessities of life—food, clothing, rent, heating, power, bus fares and so on. Hard-pressed parents who are spending money on their families and raising children—the future taxpayers—are forced by this very tax into a means tested compensation package from the outlays side of the budget.

But I want to emphasise in particular `the necessities of life'. What are they? Are they exclusively food? No, they are not. They are `food, clothing, rent, heating, power, bus fares and so on'. So to only address the taking out of food does not make that package fair. At the end of the day, it might be slightly less harsh, but it is still inequitable and it is still unfair. If one stands for the principle of fairness, then one stands against such a package.

Going back to the polling—because it is quite instructive—this week, the Australian newspaper reported the news poll taken on the basis of the GST exempting food. The first part of this news poll, which I have before me and which is important to this debate, is to see where Australia is up to as far as the GST package itself is concerned. According to this news poll, in answer to the question, `Are you for or against a GST?', the total in favour of such a tax is 40 per cent; the total against such a tax is 51 per cent. Fifty-one per cent, when I last went to school, was a majority. In other words, a majority of Australians oppose this tax; to put it around the other way, the Prime Minister has the support of only 40 per cent of Australia when it comes to this tax.

But when you look at those who are most opposed to this tax, people in households of less than $30,000 a year, only 29 per cent favour this tax. But in those households the strongest group is represented as being opposed; 46 per cent of those households are opposed to this tax. That is to say, people on low incomes know the truth; they know that this tax discriminates against them. There is the least support in that cohort against this tax, and the strongest opposition in that cohort for an opposition—a complete opposition—to the tax.

Then we come to what perhaps is the question of the day: would you be in favour of a GST if food were excluded? Not surprisingly, the majority of Australians would be; if a GST were to exclude food, 52 per cent of Australians would be in favour. Of course, that is a gun-to-the-head question: `If you are to have a tax which is a GST, would it be better with food out?' In answer, most people said yes. It is a question of appeal to the obvious and not an issue in the face of which people say, `We want a GST with food out.'

That is the critical point. In order to see that, you just go back to the first questions. To the question, `Are you for or against a GST?', 51 per cent of Australians said that they were against. Another question was: should the Senate pass this tax package? In answer, 51 per cent of Australians said that we should not, and 37 per cent of Australians said that we should. So where is the public opinion on this point? The public opinion is strongly against the government.

But there is also an important historical reference on the food-out question. Those of you who remember the Fightback package will remember that initially Fightback included food. But you will remember that on the road to the election Mr Hewson, the then leader of the coalition, removed food from the package. I have before me news poll voting intentions for the period running up to the election on 13 March 1993, the GST election we had before the last one—the one where Fightback and John Hewson were campaigning for this inequitable, unfair tax around Australia.

In December 1992, three months before the election was held, 47 per cent of Australians were going to vote for the Australian Labor Party and only 42 per cent for the Liberal-National Party, who were proposing this tax. When the food-out change was made—that is, when food was taken out by Mr Hewson—the figures reversed. In January 1993, the weekend of January 22-24, with an election looming on 13 March, 42 per cent of Australians were going to vote for the Labor Party, which was opposed to this tax; 47 per cent were going to vote for the coalition; six per cent for the Australian Democrats; and five per cent for others. So the Liberal Party took succour in the belief that they had now won the tax debate; they had swung the figures around 47 per cent in their favour.

On election eve, coming forward to the weekend of 5-7 March 1993, the figures were still the same: for the Labor Party, 42 per cent; for the food-out option of the GST, 47 per cent; for the Democrats, six per cent; and for the others, five per cent. The Liberals thought that they would win. But what happened in that election, in the real poll, was that the Liberals lost and Labor increased its majority. Indeed, after the poll that was taken on 13 March, if you go to the weekend of 2-4 April, 48 per cent were voting Labor and 42 per cent were voting Liberal.

The point about this is that it is a false dawn for anyone who believes that the food-out package is acceptable to Australia. John Hewson thought so. He lost an election believing that to be true. When people focused on the issue and asked, `Do we want a GST without food, or do we want a GST at all?', they said, `No, we don't want a GST.' They did not want a GST in 1993. If you read these polls now, they clearly say, `No, Australia does not want a GST now either, with food out; it is not an acceptable option. But, if we have the choice of a GST with food in or food out, we would prefer one with the food out.' That is the right way to read these polls.

I have one final word. Anyone debating against me will say, `But they won the last election.' They did. Labor got 52 per cent of the vote, two-party preferred; and the Liberal-National Party got 48 per cent of the vote. Their vote was spread in the electorates, which meant that the coalition got elected to government. But, if that election had been a referendum on the GST, it would not have passed; it would have failed in a majority of states and it would not have been carried overall in this country.
Senator Abetz interjecting—

talk.start.para: —So let's not come back with the argument that the last election was a referendum because, if it was one on the GST, you have lost, and the mandate question is lost with you.
—No, you're wrong.
—The government does not have a mandate in this matter. (Time expired)

—Youth unemployment is one of the major issues facing our nation today. Sadly, young people are often unemployed because they lack confidence, planning and presentation skills. I am sure that all senators would agree that the future of young Australians is of paramount importance to all of us as Australians, and it is essential that positive programs which provide training opportunities, develop leadership and planning skills and encourage initiative be endorsed and supported.

speech.para: Today I would like to inform the Senate about an exciting program in Western Australia which meets these objectives. This scheme is Cadets WA and has been introduced into Western Australia by the Minister for Youth in the Western Australian state government, the Hon. Mike Board.

talk.start.para: —A very good minister.

—A very good minister indeed, as Senator Abetz has said. The Cadets WA program provides structured training to encourage the development of practical life skills, team work and leadership qualities in young people. The vision for Cadets WA was conceptualised in 1996 by the Premier of Western Australia, the Hon. Richard Court, and Minister Mike Board became the driving force in establishing pilot cadet units in 11 schools throughout the state.

speech.para: The success of the program has been outstanding, with 139 units currently operating, the majority of which operate in schools. At present, approximately 5,000 young people are involved in the Cadets WA program.
Why is this program so important? Because it will help reduce youth unemployment, which, according to April estimates, now stands at 26.1 per cent nationally and 20.7 per cent in the state of WA.

The schools based Cadets WA program establishes an important link between training and employment which can only improve job prospects for young people when they leave school. Usually, when cadets are mentioned, one thinks of military cadets. But Cadets WA includes police rangers, emergency service cadet corps, bush rangers, St John Ambulance cadets, Red Cross cadets and the traditional navy and army cadets and air training corps.

Unfortunately, all too frequently in our local communities and in the local media our young people are viewed in a negative light, with more emphasis on the few individuals who engage in anti-social behaviour than on those who contribute positively to the community. I am sure senators would agree that it is important that our perception of young people is moulded around the positive contribution that many of them make in the community, and with the right training both in schooling and character we have the opportunity to provide young people with a solid foundation for their futures.

Cadets WA works to support community youth organisations in projecting a positive image of our youth through active participation in the program. By providing a skills based focus in the cadet organisations, participants can gain productive knowledge while also acquiring a sense of community responsibility and service. The Cadets WA program aims to provide a vocational link through which skills are recognised. Some schools have incorporated the program into their routine curriculum, while in others Cadets WA is an after school option.

Cadets WA units are totally funded by government. A management committee oversees the administration and expenditure of the program and consists of a school principal, or their representative, parent representatives and representatives from the cadet unit. Host organisations provide sponsorship and play a large role in facilitating the training activities. The level of commitment required of cadets largely depends on the type of unit. However, in general terms, it usually involves a minimum of two years training, one weekend training activity per term and an annual camp to consolidate the skills developed.

Decisions about which type of cadet training will be undertaken at the school are made by the school community after consultation with staff, students and parents. Teachers also have the opportunity to participate as instructors and unit administrators. Cadet units usually consist of 50 cadets with a minimum of three instructors or administrators. The various kinds of cadet units offer different kinds of training, but they all emphasise planning, team work, acquisition of skills and leadership.

The most popular cadet program is the emergency services cadets. These cadets strive for a broader community focus by learning from the state emergency service agencies, such as the fire brigade and rescue service, the bushfire service and the WA state emergency services. These cadets learn about rescue techniques, fire safety and basic firefighting, radio communications, first aid, navigation, bush craft, counterdisaster training, and boat and water safety. Acquiring such operational knowledge is a perfect training ground for community service and provides crisis training in case of an emergency. Many of these units also receive support from the St John Ambulance, local RSL branches, WA police services and organisations like Rotary.

Police rangers are sponsored by the police service through the Federation of Western Australian Police and Citizens Youth Clubs. As part of the Cadets WA program, the police rangers complement the WA police services schools-based policing program. Police rangers are usually aged between 11 and 18 and participate in a training program which includes survival techniques, navigation, bush craft, abseiling and climbing, all of which provide adventure and skills development to the young people involved.

Bush ranger cadets are a recent addition to the program and offer a unique opportunity for environmentally minded young people to learn about conservation and management of our natural environment. Working closely with the Department of Conservation and Land Management, which sponsors the bush rangers cadet units, bush rangers are taught the meaning of conservation, landscape and environmental management, park and reserve management, bush craft and survival skills and working safely in the natural environment. This program provides a unique opportunity to gain an understanding of the environment and the way in which individuals can contribute to its management and conservation.

The St John Ambulance cadets provide young people with an opportunity to learn about the value of good health, accident prevention, illness, first aid and family care. Cadets are able to work towards the completion of a certificate, thus providing lifelong skills in first aid and an understanding of health issues. Red Cross cadets, which are the newest type of cadet unit in the Cadets WA program, cover similar areas. Cadets in the Red Cross unit are encouraged to develop a concern and appreciation for the wellbeing of others through tolerance and acceptance, by assisting children, older persons, families and people with disabilities.

Then there are the three different kinds of military cadet units. The navel cadets encourage the development of seamanship training skills, which ensures an active interest in the RAN. The cadets participate in activities such as marine engineering, communications, catering, physical training and adventure training which can only promote confidence and active team work. The Army cadets are a voluntary youth organisation sponsored by the Australian Army and are open to young people between 13 and 19 years of age. These cadets are encouraged to gain an awareness and appreciation of Army knowledge and discipline. The Air Training Corps is a voluntary national community based youth organisation which is sponsored by the RAAF. Training activities include fieldcraft, survival, flying both powered aircraft and gliders, drill and ceremonial activities, aircraft recognition, instructional techniques and service knowledge.

The great merit of the Cadets WA program is that it primarily promotes a positive image of youth through active participation and consultation with schools, parents, local agencies and, most importantly, other young people. All of this means that the 5,000 young people involved in Cadets WA programs develop a positive outlook about life and are far less likely to fall into the deadening trap of unemployment because they have learned to use their initiative in solving problems and finding a positive pathway through life.

I would like in the Senate today to commend the WA Minister for Youth, the Hon. Mike Board, on the success of his initiative and for his enthusiasm in promoting the Cadets WA program. I feel confident that many young Western Australians will reap enormous rewards from the training they have received from the Cadets WA program during their secondary education. Already, in every state and territory of the Commonwealth, there is a model and infrastructure for similar programs to the Cadets WA program. In the light of the success of the Cadets WA program, it would be a great thing to expand on that program and see it introduced into other states to work towards a national cadet program for the youth of Australia.

talk.start.para: —I would like to endorse the comments that Senator Eggleston has just made in support of the cadet movement in Western Australia and the fantastic support role that the Hon. Mike Board has given to the cadet movement within Western Australia. The cadet movement is something from which the youth of this country have a lot to gain. The federal government went to the last election on a policy of giving an extra $3 million for cadets in schools. Unfortunately, only the Western Australian, Victorian and Queensland governments have taken us up on that offer.

speech.para: The cadet movement has been adequately explained by Senator Eggleston, so I will not comment any further on that. Suffice it to say that in my role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence I have responsibility for the cadet movement. As I travel around Australia, I am continually impressed by the fantastic contribution of the parent support groups, the volunteers and the cadets themselves. If ever a young person was deciding whether or not to get involved in the cadet movement, allow me to advise them of some anecdotal evidence that I received from a relatively small country town the other week.

The anecdotal evidence is this: youth unemployment in that township is around 80 per cent. Those youths which have involved themselves in the cadet movement nearly always obtain employment. The reason? Because they have learnt certain life skills, they have learnt how to operate as a team, cooperate with others for a common good, and they have certain discipline instilled within them which makes them ideal employees. The comments which Senator Eggleston has made in the chamber today are comments which I wholeheartedly endorse.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.57 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In light of the current reports that the government is planning to raid the surplus to buy off the Democrats on a GST deal, will the minister guarantee on behalf of the Prime Minister that the budget surplus will not be further eroded to pay for a deal on the GST with the Democrats, including the removal of food?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —It really is extraordinary. What was the attitude of the Labor Party when our government took the hard decisions to rein in public expenditure, which ultimately created the surplus that Senator Faulkner is now wanting to preserve? The Labor Party opposed us at every step. The Labor Party said it was not necessary—because the Labor Party stand for high taxes and high borrowings. We saw it after the 1993 election when they promised at the election that taxes would come down, and yet in their first budget they put taxes up, particularly indirect taxes. We saw it with borrowings year after year.

answer.para: I remind Senator Faulkner that the Labor Party created $80 billion of debt in their last five years of government. That was the Labor Party's record—high deficits. They did not worry about deficits. When we used to come in here and say, `Deficits are bad policy because they end up in interest rates being forced up and small businesses suffering,' they said to us, `We don't know what you're talking about. Deficits can be good policy.' I can remember Mr Keating as Prime Minister year after year arguing for high deficits.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. As you would be aware, I asked Senator Hill a question as to whether he would give a guarantee on behalf of the Prime Minister that the budget surplus would not be further eroded in the development of a deal on the GST with the Australian Democrats. We have had a lengthy introduction, irrelevant to the question, from Senator Hill. Could you now direct the minister to answer the question and to indicate to the Senate whether he is willing to give such a guarantee?
—I am sure Senator Hill is aware of the question, and I am sure he is leading to it.

—I would be much happier to give that guarantee if the Labor Party had done one thing to assist us in the creation of the surplus, which now Senator Faulkner says is so precious. But instead they blocked us at every stage and day after day came in here and argued against the economic policies that have resulted in the surplus. I have said time and time again that we are pleased that we took those hard but fair decisions that have resulted in that surplus because we are now able to give it back to the Australian people in benefits: the lowest interest rates in 30 years, the lowest rates of inflation in 30 years—real benefits for Australians.

answer.para: We are not going to throw away this surplus. We think it is critical to long-term sound economic policies that can provide for future generations of Australians the prosperity and jobs that we would like to provide. We have put in place sound economic policies that have been recognised around the world. They have been recognised as world's best practice. They have helped us achieve high levels of growth at a time when our markets have been in deep despair in terms of their economic capabilities. So we are not going to throw away those surpluses; they are going to help sustain our economic strength.

But we are also interested in tax reform that gives us the opportunity to build upon our economic gains. We have to do more—there are still unemployed in Australia. We want to build upon our economic achievements so far and to provide future jobs. Senator Faulkner can be assured that we have taken good, sound economic decisions, we have delivered the benefits to the Australian people and we are not going to throw that away. But we are committed to a tax reform that will further encourage economic growth and that will encourage Australians to take risks and to go out there and build their businesses and employ Australians who are still out of work. Senator Faulkner need not worry; we will not sacrifice sound economic policy, because we actually believe in it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister now give a clear and categorical commitment to the parliament that the surplus will not be raided to pay for a food-free GST? Will you give that commitment—that guarantee—now, on behalf of the Prime Minister, to the parliament and to the Australian people?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —As I said, the Labor Party is extraordinary. All of a sudden it is interested in surpluses and says they should be preserved, after building $80 billion of debt in its last five years of government. All of a sudden, it is interested in food remaining in the GST. It can vote for a GST with food, but it will not vote for a GST with food.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Could you direct the Leader of the Government in the Senate to answer the clear question that I directed to him in relation to giving that guarantee on behalf of the Prime Minister? He has an opportunity to answer it in the 30 seconds that remain to him. Would you direct him to do so?
—Senator Faulkner, I cannot direct him how to answer this question. I am sure the minister is aware of the question that has been asked, and he is dealing with it as he believes is relevant.

—I think the Labor Party have a nerve, being the policy free zone that they are, to ask a question of this type. Yes, I will guarantee that we will not sacrifice sound economic policy, because we support it. We have the runs on the board, and we want to build upon those achievements because we want the economy to grow and we want to create more jobs for Australians.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Ellison. Minister, given the present level of concern in the community about illicit drug misuse by younger Australians, will you inform the Senate of any initiatives the government has taken recently in relation to drug education? Will you also advise the Senate as to any strategy undertaken by the government in this regard, particularly with reference to cooperation with the state and territory governments?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —Yesterday was an important day for drug education in this country because we saw the launch by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Trish Worth, of the government's National School Drug Education strategy. This is the first time that we have a nationally funded and coordinated strategy dealing with this very important question of school drug education. This is a strategy which has as its basic goal no illicit drugs in schools. It is a strategy which says that illicit drugs have no place whatsoever in schools and it forms a part of this government's Tough on Drugs strategy. That was mentioned yesterday by my colleague Senator Vanstone when she referred to the three arms of this strategy: firstly, law enforcement; secondly, the health area of harm minimisation; and, thirdly, the important area of education.

answer.para: But what we have here is a national strategy which came about as a result of the hard work by the National Advisory Committee on School Drug Education, which was set up by this government to look at this important question. I think it is important to look at the goal stated by this strategy, which is:

The National School Drug Education Strategy strengthens the provision of educational programs and supportive environments which contribute to the goal of `no illicit drugs in schools'. This goal is based on the belief that illicit and other unsanctioned drug use in schools is unacceptable. The focus will be on educational outcomes. Assisting students with drug related problems and deterring the presence and use of unsanctioned drugs in schools will also be addressed.

Part of Senator Brownhill's question dealt with our cooperation with state and territory governments. That is of course a very import ant aspect because the delivery of this strategy is primarily in the hands of state and territory governments. It was through the ministerial council of education ministers that we developed cooperation on this very important subject, and I am pleased to say that we have had cooperation from all governments in this respect. In fact, the ministerial council of education ministers has now set up a task force to see this matter through.

This government remains firmly committed to the problem of drugs and how they affect our young people. At the outset, we committed $7½ million to the development of this strategy and the implementation of it. In accordance with our electoral promises, we have committed a further $10.5 million in our budget this year to the further implementation of this drug strategy. This of course cannot be dealt with by governments alone; we need the help of parents and communities, and this is part of the drug strategy that we have developed. The Advisory Committee on School Drug Education which I have mentioned has done an excellent job in bringing about this strategy. But its work is not yet finished; it has to help the government implement this. Over the forthcoming years it will look at programs which are effective and will offer international best practice to our schools and, particularly, teachers. This strategy focuses on the professional development of teachers in dealing with this. This is a very important strategy which is a step forward in the fight against drugs.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you very much, Minister. I recently attended a country cities against drugs meeting in Tamworth, and that made all the points that you have just made. Minister, how long will the government's program take?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —This government has committed $500 million over the next four years to its Tough on Drugs program, and the funding I referred to earlier in relation to this strategy covers the next four years. But this problem is not going to be solved overnight; it will require a generational change in relation to drugs.
—It won't be solved by you.

—I hear the interjection by Senator Bolkus and I invite him to join the government in its fight against drugs, because it will need the efforts of this government and of future Australian governments to fight this crisis in Australian society.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The bickering and the interjections of the opposition will not help. Why don't they join with us in fighting this big problem?

—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. It is an important question about the government backsliding on tax avoidance. Can the minister confirm that the government remains committed to reforming the taxation treatment of family trusts as outlined in its ANTS package, notwithstanding the reported comment by the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, `We'll kill this in cabinet'?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —We went to the election, as you will be quite aware, Senator Cook, outlining a comprehensive tax strategy. One aspect, of course, was the current bills before the parliament and the other one was the reform of business taxes. Those issues on trusts are now before the Ralph committee. The government is waiting for the recommendations of the Ralph committee and will respond to those recommendations in due course. Let me say that we are very committed to tax reform: we are committed to the reform of the income tax system, the indirect tax system and the business tax system, Senator. Let me give you that absolute assurance.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Well, I heard the answer, but was it yes or was it no, Minister? Can you assure the Senate that at least you and the Treasurer will stand firm on the issue of family trusts in the face of mounting National Party pressure?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator, let me give you an absolute assurance: I am in favour of tax reform. I am in favour of the commitments that we made in the course of the election.
—Which ones are they?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—In relation to trusts and a wide range of other issues that have gone to the Ralph committee, the government will be making its decision on the basis of the recommendations that come forward from Mr Ralph's committee.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone. The fight against crime is an important issue for the security of all Australians. Will the minister inform the Senate of the government's budget initiatives for the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service and the National Crime Authority?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Justice and Customs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Coonan for her question.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is no wonder that Senator Bolkus does not want to listen, having presided over many years of Labor inefficiency in this area.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, you will cease interjecting. You are in breach of the standing orders. There is an appropriate time for you to raise issues.

—Senator Bolkus would recognise, privately of course, that this is an excellent and far-sighted budget for Australia's premier law enforcement agencies—the Australian Federal Police, Customs, the National Crime Authority and AUSTRAC. The budget implements the government's promises in full. It delivers the resources that law enforcement agencies need to carry out their work.

answer.para: Let me focus on just a few highlights in this budget for law enforcement agencies. Perhaps one of the most important is up to $50 million over three years to establish a national crime information system called Crimtrack. Crimtrack will give local police the tools they need to fight crime locally. It will provide access to the most up-to-date and efficient technology to store and retrieve information to help police. It will build a national DNA criminal intelligence database and a national child sex offender database. After that, there will be $41.6 million for the Tough on Drugs strategy to expand Australia's capacity to intercept drugs before they reach Australia's shores and to attack the distribution networks in Australia. Those funds will go to the Federal Police, the National Crime Authority and AUSTRAC.

There will be an amount of $35.4 million over four years for the Australian Customs Service to significantly increase its ability to detect illegal drugs. That will include new large-scale X-ray technology and funding to support specialist ship and aircraft search teams. After that, there will be $24.2 million over four years for an additional four mobile strike teams for the Australian Federal Police under the Tough on Drugs strategy. That will bring the total number of those teams to 10. Under the Labor Party, the Australian Federal Police had the capacity to mount only one—a singular one, Senator Bolkus—proactive drug importation investigation at any one time. There will be $6.5 million for Customs activities associated with the Olympics.

Those initiatives together mean that over the next four years there will be a new $157.7 million available for law enforcement in Australia. Of course, you do not only need to fight crime when it has happened; this government is far-sighted enough to see that we need to put significant resources into crime prevention. So in addition to re-funding the national campaign against violence and crime, we have added $8 million or so for crime prevention programs targeted quite specifically to families and family breakdown.

The Labor Party ran a record of budget deficits. It had no meaningful commitment at all to our premier law enforcement agencies. Mr Beazley finally agreed on 2GB recently that money had been restored to law enforcement. He admitted that it had been increased in February and at that time was greater than it had been before—this was before the budget—but went on to say that it was never terribly adequate anyway. That is what Mr Beazley said about the law enforcement funding of the Labor Party in their 13 years in government: it was never terribly adequate anyway. We have not only restored funding; we have also increased it dramatically in this budget. Senator Faulkner and others might like to bear in mind that that is what you can afford to do when you run the economy properly.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator Herron. I ask: on this National Sorry Day, can the minister inform the Senate whether the government is still refusing to offer an apology to the stolen generations and whether this refusal is based on the need to avoid Commonwealth legal liability for the removal of children and their families? Isn't this prime ministerial excuse directly contradicted by the government's own budget papers, at page 4-31, where the government sets out the risks to the Commonwealth's fiscal position from the 2,200 claimants, which are in the realm of some `hundreds of millions of dollars'? Isn't it the case that the government continues to ignore the precedent set by state and territory governments purely because the Prime Minister is too stubborn and too narrow-minded to undertake a real act of reconciliation?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Bolkus for the question. I should inform the Senate that Senator Bolkus and I were on the stage today singing a duet.
—You were late.

—That is true. I acknowledge Senator Faulkner's comment that I was late. I was late because I was meeting with the Commonwealth Grants Commission. We were discussing the very real problems of disadvantage in the Aboriginal community. It was a very constructive meeting. We were addressing the problems that the Labor Party left us as a legacy after 13 years of administering this portfolio.

answer.para: The Prime Minister and I have personally expressed our sorrow for the events that have occurred in the past. But no country must be held hostage to its past, as Senator Bolkus would appear to suggest. No country can be held hostage to its past. We have to get on with redressing the problems of the present and planning the future. Senator Bolkus brought up the question of compensation and tried to link it to that.

Under the Keating government, common law cases for compensation were started before the Bringing them home report was brought in. They were under way when you were in government, Senator Bolkus. What did the Keating government do? They responded as the government of the day, as we are today, in relation to compensation. So it is a spurious argument to bring up. The facts are that the compensation cases started under the Keating government when that government defended the original separated children litigation in the case of Kruger and Bray. That is fact. The writs for the Cubillo and Gunner cases were filed in October 1996—six months before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report was published and called for a national apology. To now start trying to distort the past to suit the political expediency of the present opposition is not correct. I think those remarks should be put on the board.

We are addressing the problems of the past in a very constructive way, in relation to health, housing, education and employment. Madam President, you would be aware that only in the last day Minister Reith and Minister Abbott announced an employment program specifically for indigenous people of this country, to redress those problems that have resulted.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. My point of order goes to relevance. Senator Herron is being asked about an apology—an apology which the Prime Minister will not give, but an apology which other state and territory leaders will give. I have asked the minister why the government and the Prime Minister will not tender an apology. I have not asked him anything about all these other matters he is talking about. On a point of relevance, he should answer the question that has been put to him, not be allowed to ramble about other aspects of Aboriginal affairs.
—On the point of order, Senator Herron.

—Senator Bolkus did not listen to what I said. I addressed the question that he asked. He as usual adopts his continuous attitude of sledging across the chamber without putting his brain and his hearing apparatus in order so that he can hear what was said.
—There is no point of order. I think the minister is aware of the question. I think the minister was initially distracted by interjections, which would be best ignored.

—We are addressing the present and planning the future, and we are doing that constructively. In the last budget we brought down a $2.2 billion indigenous specific budget which is the greatest ever in the history of this country. We have responded to the Bringing them home report in a $63 million package that is constructively addressing the report that was presented by the inquiry. We are looking into the Link Up programs. We have set all those things in order and we are bringing out and addressing the disadvantage that obviously exists in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community of this country. We will not get anywhere if we do not address those things. As I said previously, we have a legacy of 13 years of Labor: when they had the opportunity to do all those things and did nothing.

—As a supplementary question, I place on record that, though we were on the same stage, Senator Herron had neither a voice nor money to help the people this morning in the Great Hall. I ask the minister: if the government had had the good sense and the common decency to issue an apology in response to the stolen generations report, couldn't we have avoided the situation we find ourselves in—that is, mired in a test case in Darwin that has already cost $6 million, under daily instruction from your and the Prime Minister's offices, and preparing to fight some 2,000 further cases at a cost of hundreds of millions of dollars to the taxpayer? Wouldn't an apology at least mitigate some of those costs?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Madam President, again he did not listen to what I had said previously. The apology appeared in the response of the Bringing them home report. The compensation cases were started prior to that. There was no question then about apologies. The government has stated its position in relation to that.

subdebateinfo.title: Disability Discrimination Legislation: Right of Appeal

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. I refer to the minister's answer to my question yesterday that disability discrimination was a matter for the Attorney-General. How can the minister say that when the interests of people with disabilities are her concern? Again I remind the minister of the National Mental Health Statement of Rights and Responsibilities, which states:

question.para: The consumer has the right to information on and access to mechanisms of complaint and redress and to appeal decisions made regarding their treatment and care.

Can I at least ask the minister to indicate if she supports that statement. Furthermore, can the minister tell the Senate whether she was even consulted in the drafting of the regulations that now prevent some disabled people from making a complaint under the Disability Discrimination Act?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Allison is still labouring under a misapprehension. I am the minister responsible for provision of employment services to people with disabilities and also for the provision of income support for people with disabilities. The responsibility for the legal protection of people with disabilities is in the Attorney-General's portfolio, as I said to her yesterday. Of course I am concerned about it, Senator, but you asked me a question which was appropriately addressed to the Attorney-General's portfolio, and Senator Vanstone was here ready, willing and eager to answer your question. I work with people from disability organisations and the care organisations constantly and of course I am concerned that they be properly protected under the law. But my responsibilities are in the provision of the appropriate disability employment services and their income support.

—I ask a supplementary question. The minister says that she is responsible for seeing that people with disabilities are properly protected under the law. I thought that was my question. I ask her again whether she supports the statement that I have just mentioned and whether she can give us some assurances that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the minister herself and people with disabilities will be consulted in the drafting of any future regulations which exempt the operation of the DDA?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
