There are no problems with that. But tonight I am trying to tell you that this matter with respect to exploration is so serious in Western Australia that it does affect the whole nation. Without the Native Title Act, we would have had 10,000 more tenements operating in exploration. No tenements, no prospecting; no prospecting, no drillers—half of whom have their rigs idle now anyway. With no drillers, there can be no mines. With no mines, there is no work. With no work in our mineral industries, there can be no exports.

I will finish by reminding the Senate that over 26 per cent of exports come from Western Australia, which has 9.8 per cent of Australia's population. Those exports will diminish. We are mining yesterday's discoveries. We need to fix the Native Title Act legally. If we do not, we simply need to referendum the problem away.

talk.start.para: —As many in this chamber have observed, one of the most profound developments of the 20th century has been the rise of technology and the emergence of a global economy. We are living in an age of rapid change and technological development, and this has led to dramatic upheavals in the traditional social, economic and cultural givens, particularly in rural and regional Australia—and the face of rural Australia is changing.

speech.para: In 1900 two-thirds of Australians lived in non-metropolitan areas; after World War II that figure had dropped to just below 50 per cent; and now only one-third of Australians live in regional Australia. Yet in 1997-98, primary industries, agriculture, forestry, mining—the area that Senator Lightfoot was just so impassioned about—and energy contributed more than $70 billion towards GDP, which is no mean feat.

So why do people leave the bush? The benefits of globalisation and competition have been uneven, adversely affecting traditional family businesses in some areas. Job opportunities are predominantly to be found in towns and cities. Indeed, when I think about it, that is the reason for my being here and not living in Mangoplah, New South Wales.

talk.start.para: —I'm sure there were other reasons.

—The subsequent loss of population results in a withdrawal of vital community services in small towns. Senator Evans says that there probably were other reasons. There might be one or two, Senator Evans, although I must say that I harbour the fondest feelings for Mangoplah. The emergence of sponge cities—like my bigger home town of Wagga Wagga, and Dubbo, in New South Wales—have been growing at the expense of the surrounding countryside.

speech.para: Undoubtedly there is evidence that rural and regional Australia are suffering, at least in pockets. Thirty-three of the 37 poorest federal electorates in Australia are rural. Youth unemployment is up to three times the national average. Wages and living standards are well below the national average. In some rural and regional communities, there is a wait of up to two months for a consultation with a GP. Of course, the consequences are that there are higher rates of depression and alcoholism; youth suicide rates—and this is particularly alarming—are 13 times the national average; one in five heroin deaths occurs in country Australia; and drug-related crime has reached unprecedented levels, with burglary rising over the last five years by 50 per cent in Dubbo, 41 per cent in Orange and 40 per cent in Coffs Harbour.

So some important questions need to be addressed. Is Australia becoming two nations? Have globalisation, competition policy and domestic structural change created a society characterised by urban haves and rural have-nots?

There is no doubt that parts of rural and regional Australia are struggling to come to terms with rapid global change and, as a result, face complex and profound problems that need ongoing national attention and action. It has become a popular Australian pastime to lay the blame for both the economic downturn and the political disenchantment in the bush at the feet of competition and competition policy. As competition policy has enjoyed bipartisan support and been pursued vigorously since Australia's nine governments jointly agreed to implement the national competition policy package in 1995, it is critically important as a matter of public debate to identify whether the policy has produced the anticipated benefits.

To place the blame primarily on competition policy not only is simplistic but also shows a misunderstanding of the long-term factors, primarily globalisation and technological changes, that have been the real drivers of structural change in rural and regional communities Australia wide. The release this month of the Productivity Commission's Draft report on the impact of competition policy reforms on rural and regional Australia has confirmed that competition policy does in fact greatly benefit rural communities, both economically and socially, and has reinforced the notion that much of the criticism and blame has been misdirected and that the process is misunderstood. The draft report has concluded that competition policy has become a convenient whipping boy or scapegoat for the social and economic problems that have impacted rural and regional Australia.

The adoption of a coordinated approach to reform on a national basis recognises the growing reality of Australia as a single market rather than as a series of markets delineated by state borders. The objective is not to pursue competition as an end in itself but, where appropriate, to inject competition into previously sheltered areas of the economy and to create more efficient use of the nation's electricity, water, gas and road transport infrastructure. The aim is to promote growth and raise the real incomes of Australian households.

One of the most positive conclusions of the draft Productivity Commission report is that, on a conservative estimate, national output would be around 2.5 per cent higher if competition reform were taken to the next level, with positive and profound ramifications for country Australia. In simple terms, if rural and regional Australia is to succeed in the new world order dominated by technological change and a global marketplace, then competition must be embraced—and embraced sooner rather than later. Alan Wood, writing in the Australian earlier this week, made this very pertinent statement:
Failure to implement competition reform cannot stop the impact of broader economic and social forces but only deny Australia the benefits of the reforms themselves.

It is gratifying to learn that consumers, user industries and governments are already deriving benefits from national competition policy reforms. It is timely to remind the Senate and those listening to this debate tonight of just a few examples. Electricity bills have fallen about 23 to 30 per cent on average and up to 60 per cent in some instances for those New South Wales and Victorian businesses covered by the national competitive market, while wholesale prices for electricity have fallen around 23 per cent since its internal competitive market commenced. Gas prices for major industrial users fell about 50 per cent after the deregulation of the Pilbara market in 1995, while gas distribution tariffs are set to fall 60 per cent by the year 2000 in New South Wales compared with 1997 levels.

Rail freight is another example. Rail freight rates for grain in Western Australia have fallen 21 per cent in real terms since deregulation in 1992-93, while rail freights for the Perth-Melbourne route fell 40 per cent and service quality and transport times improved following the introduction of competition in 1995.

To take a totally different example: conveyancing fees in New South Wales fell 17 per cent between 1994 and 1996 after the abolition of the legal profession's monopoly and the removal of price scheduling and advertising restrictions, leading to an annual saving to consumers of at least $86 million. At least that is a start to provide some sort of access to justice in legal matters.

Over the four years to 1995-96, the prices for goods and services provided by various government trading enterprises made back to their governments actually doubled—due in part to competition reforms. In Queensland, 10 of the 17 largest local councils have implemented two-part tariffs for water, resulting in an average saving in water usage of 20 per cent in the first year. This is a very good one: following a review of business licensing in New South Wales that had found significant duplication and overlap, some 72 licences have been able to be repealed and more are being looked at. Among other changes, 44 categories have been collapsed into just three.

The role of competition in the delivery of services is vital, and nobody realises this more than the government. Obviously, competition policy is not a panacea. But it does go a very long way towards providing better services, competition and much fairer outcomes for people who have suffered too long in the bush.
Senate adjourned at 7.57 p.m.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Bookmakers' Margins.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 431)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST) be imposed on bookmakers' margins.

(2) Have all states agreed to drop state-based taxes applying to bookmakers if a GST is imposed on their margins; if so; (a) which states have agreed; and (b) when were those agreements reached; if not, will a GST be imposed on bookmakers' margins in addition to the state-based taxes they pay currently.
(3) Has Treasury undertaken any assessment of the amount of revenue a GST would collect from the bookmaking industry.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) GST will apply to bookmakers' gambling margin as set out in Division 126 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998. Bookmakers registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits to offset any GST paid on business purchases.
(2) In respect of State taxes on gambling, the tax reform document "Tax Reform—not a new tax—a new tax system" (ANTS) noted that:

"As the States already tax gambling highly there may need to be corresponding reductions in State gambling taxes. This will be possible because, under the proposed arrangements, the States will receive the proceeds of the GST, including the GST on gambling."

Accordingly, the States and Territories signed the Intergovernmental Agreement at the Premiers Conference on 9 April 1999 agreeing to adjust their gambling taxation arrangements to take account of the impact of the GST on gambling operators.
(3) Treasury has not specifically estimated GST revenue from the bookmaking industry.

subdebateinfo.title: Precision Approach Radar Monitoring System: Trial
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 672)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 13 April 1999:

(2) Has the Minister determined that he will assess the environmental impact of the PRM system by way of a public environment report or an environmental impact statement.
(3) (a) What was the basis of his decision; (b) when will the assessment process commence; and (c) how long will the process take.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1), (2), (3) No such proposal related to the Precision Approach Radar Monitoring (PRM) system has been referred to me.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 27 April 1999:

question.para: (1) When was the Asian Infrastructure Consortia program first introduced.
(3) What assessment of the importance or potential of the program was made prior to its abolition.
(4) How many applications for loans under the program were received.
(5) (a) How many loans were approved; (b) what was their value
(6) Were any applications outstanding at the time the program was abolished.

(7) Did any of the loan recipients referred to in (5): (a) receive the money approved; (b) form the proposed consortia to tender for contracts; and (c) win any contracts; if so, what was the value of contracts: (i) for which tenders were submitted, and (ii) won by successful Australian recipients of the program.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Asian Infrastructure Consortia Program (AICP) was introduced in September 1994.
(2) The AICP was abolished in 1996.
(3) The ACIP was abolished as part of the Government's election platform in 1996.
(4) Nineteen applications had been received as of 5 February 1996. Five applications were subsequently withdrawn.
(5) (a) Five loans were approved. (b) The total value of approved loans was $2.95 million.
(6) Commitments entered into for the 1995/96 fiscal year were honoured, but no funds were available from 1996/97.
(7) (a) Yes; (b) Yes; (c) No.
